Sign In My Account Log Out

Component: Header

Introduction

When you're ready to install this, you'll also want to add header.js to your application. This is part of the node_modules/@tesla/particles package installed, so you'll want to manage that addition yourself somehow.

Selected class

In addition to the javascript file noted above, you'll also want to build a way to show the "selected" menu item. This has been styled using .tsla-header-nav--selected on the <li> element containing the Selected Menu Item.

Account/Authentication Links

Note: This is only Phase 1. There is more work coming to accommodate a more holistic approach to this information.

Nearly all web applications are managing some sort of user authentication or user account information. Providing a way to display this state is necessary across all applications. Provided herein are some helper classes and the definition around those helper classes to guide you in building this piece out.

In addition to the above optional color scheme, This version of particles includes the ability to situate your user's authenticated state within the application. Following the guide outlined below to generate the styling desired.

Desired UI

Listed below is the documentation around the "rules and regulations" related to the User Account/Authentication links.

  • When viewed in a desktop-sized viewport (640px and above), the Account link(s) are in the top, primary menu to the far right next to the menu drawer icon.
  • When viewed in a mobile-sized viewport (640px and below), the Account link(s) are attached to the bottom of the drawer.
  • When the "more" option is toggled open (if your application has this enabled), the Account link(s) are pushed to the bottom of the drawer (i.e. the Account links should never overlap the content in the drawer.
Class Name Location Purpose
.tsla-user_is--logged-out body tag or wrapper around header code Helper class to style based on user is logged out
.tsla-user_is--logged-in body tag or wrapper around header code Helper class to style based on user is logged in
.tsla-link_for-login attached to the "Sign in" link(s) Toggles visibility of user is logged out links
.tsla-link_for-logout attached to the "My Account" link(s) Toggles visiblity of user is logged in links
.tsla-subdued added to the "sign out" link" The logout link should be a bit darker than the other links, so provide some separation.

Header color variations

Included in the styles here are the following variants on the Tesla header:

Class Name Background Color Link Color Description
n/a #222222 #ffffff The default header styling applied to all pages if nothing else is specified
.tsla-header-alternate #ffffff #222222 The inverse of the default header.
.tsla-header-semitransparent #222222 @ 75% transparent #ffffff Positioned absolutely such that the page's content will flow under the header. Particularly useful on pages with large hero images
.tsla-header-transparent--dark n/a #222222 Positioned absolutely such that the page's content will flow under the header. Particularly useful on pages with large hero images
.tsla-header-transparent--light n/a #ffffff Positioned absolutely such that the page's content will flow under the header. Particularly useful on pages with large hero images
.tsla-header-transparent n/a #ffffff Deprecated Do not use

Default Header

Tesla, Inc

  1. Selected Menu Item
    • Sign In
  1. Secondary
    1. Tertiary
▲ 
<div>
  <input type="checkbox" id="tsla-header-nav--secondary_show" class="tsla-header-checkbox">
  <header id="tsla-header-main" class="tsla-header-main">
    <div class="tsla-header-main--container">
      <div class="container">
        <h1 id="tesla-logo" class="tsla-header-main--logo_container">
          <a href="/" class="tsla-header-main--logo" title="Tesla Motors">Tesla, Inc</a>
        </h1>
        <input type="checkbox" id="tsla-header-main--trigger" class="tsla-header-checkbox">
        <label for="tsla-header-main--trigger">
          <span class="tsla-header-main--trigger_icon">
            <i class="tsla-header-main--cross_hatch">&times;</i>
          </span>
        </label>
        <nav class="tsla-header-nav">
          <div class="tsla-header-nav--primary">
            <ol class="tsla-header-nav--list">
              <li class="tsla-header-nav--list_item tsla-header-nav--selected">
                <a href="/styleguide" title="" class="tsla-header-nav--list_link">Selected Menu Item</a>
              </li>
              <li class="tsla-header-nav--list_item tsla-header-nav--list_item_last">
                <ul class="tsla-header-nav--list tsla-header-nav--primary_right">
                  <li class="tsla-header-nav--list_item tsla-header-nav--auth_link">
                    <a href="/styleguide" title="" class="tsla-header-nav--list_link tsla-link_for-login">Sign In</a>
                  </li>
                </ul>
              </li>
              <!-- as many as you want -->
            </ol>
          </div>
          <div class="tsla-header-nav--secondary">
            <label for="tsla-header-nav--secondary_show" class="tsla-header-nav--list_link">
              More <span class="tsla-header--more_caret">&rsaquo;</span>
            </label>
            <ol class="tsla-header-nav--list tsla-header-nav--parent_nav">
              <li class="tsla-header-nav--list_item">
                <a href="#" title="Tesla.com" class="tsla-header-nav--list_link">Secondary</a>
                <ol class="tsla-header-nav--list">
                  <li class="tsla-header-nav--list_item">
                    <a href="#" title="Tesla.com" class="tsla-header-nav--list_link">Tertiary</a>
                  </li>
                  <!-- as many as you want -->
                </ol>
              </li>
              <!-- as many as you want -->
            </ol>
          </div>
        </nav>
        <span id="tsla-header-mask"></span>
      </div>
    </div>
  </header>
</div>

Mobile Drawer Open

As an engineer, I would like to choose which side the mobile menu opens from. On the left, or on the right.

NOTE: This action only works on mobile layouts, not for the desktop drawer.

Still interested? Sweet.

By default, the nav will open from the right side, but you can override this behavior by adding .tsla-header-drawer--enter_left as a wrapper class (i.e. on the body tag or similar).

What are the classes?

Default .tsla-header-drawer--enter_left

Transparent Header (deprecated)

App Title (optional)

You might want to add an optional title to your header, such as the name of your application.

Tesla, Inc My App Name

  1. Selected Menu Item
    • Sign In
  1. Secondary
    1. Tertiary
▲ 
<div>
  <input type="checkbox" id="tsla-header-nav--secondary_show" class="tsla-header-checkbox">
  <header id="tsla-header-main" class="tsla-header-main">
    <div class="tsla-header-main--container">
      <div class="container">
        <h1 id="tesla-logo" class="tsla-header-main--logo_container">
          <a href="/" class="tsla-header-main--logo" title="Tesla Motors">Tesla, Inc</a>
          <span class="tsla-header-main--app_title">My App Name</span>
        </h1>
        <input type="checkbox" id="tsla-header-main--trigger" class="tsla-header-checkbox">
        <label for="tsla-header-main--trigger">
          <span class="tsla-header-main--trigger_icon">
            <i class="tsla-header-main--cross_hatch">&times;</i>
          </span>
        </label>
        <nav class="tsla-header-nav">
          <div class="tsla-header-nav--primary">
            <ol class="tsla-header-nav--list">
              <li class="tsla-header-nav--list_item tsla-header-nav--selected">
                <a href="/styleguide" title="" class="tsla-header-nav--list_link">Selected Menu Item</a>
              </li>
              <li class="tsla-header-nav--list_item tsla-header-nav--list_item_last">
                <ul class="tsla-header-nav--list tsla-header-nav--primary_right">
                  <li class="tsla-header-nav--list_item tsla-header-nav--auth_link">
                    <a href="/styleguide" title="" class="tsla-header-nav--list_link tsla-link_for-login">Sign In</a>
                  </li>
                </ul>
              </li>
              <!-- as many as you want -->
            </ol>
          </div>
          <div class="tsla-header-nav--secondary">
            <label for="tsla-header-nav--secondary_show" class="tsla-header-nav--list_link">
              More <span class="tsla-header--more_caret">&rsaquo;</span>
            </label>
            <ol class="tsla-header-nav--list tsla-header-nav--parent_nav">
              <li class="tsla-header-nav--list_item">
                <a href="#" title="Tesla.com" class="tsla-header-nav--list_link">Secondary</a>
